problems.title: Problems
problems.create_description: Add problems to the shared pool for use in contests and assignments
problems.select_from_pool: Choose from problems already available in the shared pool
problems.upload_new_problem: Upload a new problem to the shared pool
problems.format_markdown: Markdown (.md) - Simple format with problem statement and test cases
problems.format_zip: ZIP (.zip) - Compressed folder with assets and metadata
problems.what_included: Each problem contains the following elements
problems.clear_description: Clear and concise description of what the problem asks
problems.sample_and_hidden: Sample cases for manual testing plus hidden test cases for validation
problems.time_memory: Time limits and memory requirements for your solution
problems.difficulty_tags: Difficulty level, topic tags, and category information

submission_form.file_too_large: File is too large. Maximum size is {{size}}KB.

feedback.compilation_error: Your code has a compilation error. Check the checklist for details.
feedback.almost_there: Almost there! One test case failed.
feedback.none_passed: No test cases passed yet. Review your logic carefully.
feedback.runtime_error: Your program crashed at runtime. Check array bounds and null references.
feedback.slow_solution: Your solution is slow. Consider optimizing your algorithm.

verdicts.WA_desc: Your output doesn't match expected result for one or more test cases
verdicts.RE_desc: Your program crashed during execution (segmentation fault, null pointer, etc.)
verdicts.TLE_desc: Your solution is too slow and exceeded the time limit
verdicts.MLE_desc: Your solution used more memory than allowed
verdicts.CE_desc: Your code has syntax errors or won't compile
verdicts.PENDING_desc: Your submission is queued and waiting to be judged
verdicts.RUNNING_desc: Your code is currently being tested

cpp.syntax: Missing semicolon or bracket - check compilation error line
cpp.variables: Variable not declared - check spelling and declare before use
cpp.linking: Function/variable not linked - check if all source files are compiled
cpp.type_mismatch: Type mismatch - check data types match function parameters
cpp.type_conversion: Cannot convert type - use explicit cast: (int)value, (double)value
cpp.logic: Test case failed - check algorithm and boundary conditions
cpp.input_output: Check input format parsing and output formatting
cpp.data_types: Verify data types match input (int vs long long for large numbers)
cpp.integer_overflow: Check for overflow: int range is ~-2B to +2B. Use long long for larger values
cpp.code_quality: Consider optimizing for large inputs if needed

python.indentation: Fix indentation - ensure consistent spacing (typically 4 spaces)
python.syntax: Syntax error - check colons after if/for/while/def/class
python.variables: Variable not defined - check spelling and scope
python.types: Type error - check type conversions (int(), str(), etc.)
python.type_hints: Tip: Use int(input()) for numbers, input() returns str by default
python.index_error: Index out of range - check array bounds
python.methods: Method doesn't exist - check object type and available methods
python.type_conversion: Cannot convert value - e.g., int('abc') fails. Verify input is valid
python.logic: Test case failed - verify algorithm logic
python.data_types: Tip: Remember int/float/str are different. int('123') != '123'
python.large_numbers: Python handles big integers automatically, but check for infinite loops or recursion

javascript.syntax: Syntax error - check brackets, braces, and parentheses
javascript.variables: Variable not defined - declare with const/let/var
javascript.types: Type error - check variable types and function calls
javascript.type_coercion: Tip: Use === not ==. '5' == 5 is true, but '5' === 5 is false
javascript.null_undefined: Null or undefined error - check if value exists before using
javascript.nan: Got NaN (Not a Number) - ensure converting strings to numbers correctly: Number(x) or parseInt(x)
javascript.data_types: Tip: Remember '123' (string) != 123 (number). Use Number() to convert
javascript.large_numbers: For numbers > 2^53, use BigInt: BigInt(9007199254740991) or 123n

adminGuide.section_1_desc: Understanding your administrative responsibilities and capabilities
adminGuide.section_1_p1: The Admin Panel is a powerful management interface for overseeing the entire CodeFix AI platform.
adminGuide.section_1_p2: As an admin, you have full control over users, problems, and submissions.
adminGuide.section_1_p3: You can manage user roles, create and modify problems, delete submissions, and view comprehensive statistics.
adminGuide.section_1_p4: All administrative actions are logged for security and audit purposes.
adminGuide.section_1_p5: The admin dashboard provides real-time insights into platform usage and performance.
adminGuide.section_1_p6: Access the Admin Panel from the main navigation menu - only admins can see this option.
adminGuide.section_2_desc: How to manage user accounts, roles, and permissions
adminGuide.section_2_p1: The Users section displays all registered users on the platform with their details.
adminGuide.section_2_p2: You can search for users by username, ID, or other criteria to quickly find specific accounts.
adminGuide.section_2_p3: Role Management: Change any user's role between USER, STUDENT, TEACHER, or ADMIN.
adminGuide.section_2_p4: USER: Regular users can only solve problems and view their own submissions.
adminGuide.section_2_p5: STUDENT: Students have the same privileges as users but are marked for course tracking.
adminGuide.section_2_p6: TEACHER: Teachers can create and manage problems, view student submissions for their problems, and access analytics.
adminGuide.section_2_p7: ADMIN: Full system access. Only existing admins can promote users to admin status for security.
adminGuide.section_2_p8: Pagination helps you navigate through large user lists efficiently.
adminGuide.section_2_p9: Each user record shows join date and current role for quick reference.
adminGuide.section_3_desc: Creating, editing, and removing coding problems
adminGuide.section_3_p1: The Problems section allows you to manage the entire problem library.
adminGuide.section_3_p2: Create New Problems: Click 'Create Problem' to add new coding challenges to the platform.
adminGuide.section_3_p3: Edit Problem Data: Modify problem titles, descriptions, statements, difficulty levels, and resource limits.
adminGuide.section_3_p4: Edit Testcases: Add, update, or remove test cases that validate user submissions.
adminGuide.section_3_p5: Difficulty Levels: Set problems as EASY, MEDIUM, or HARD to help users find appropriate challenges.
adminGuide.section_3_p6: Resource Limits: Configure time limits (milliseconds) and memory limits (megabytes) for each problem.
adminGuide.section_3_p7: Visibility: Control which users can see each problem (published vs draft).
adminGuide.section_3_p8: Problem Statistics: View how many users have solved each problem and the solution acceptance rate.
adminGuide.section_3_p9: Delete Problems: Remove problems that are no longer relevant (this will delete related submissions too).
adminGuide.section_3_p10: Search & Filter: Quickly find problems by title, difficulty, or category.
adminGuide.section_4_p1: The Submissions section shows all code submissions from users across all problems.
adminGuide.section_4_p2: Filter submissions by verdict status: ACCEPTED, WRONG_ANSWER, TIME_LIMIT_EXCEEDED, COMPILATION_ERROR, etc.
adminGuide.section_4_p3: View detailed information about each submission including user, problem, language, and timestamp.
adminGuide.section_4_p4: Performance Metrics: See execution time and memory usage for each submission.
adminGuide.section_4_p5: View Source Code: Click on any submission to review the user's code.
adminGuide.section_4_p6: Delete Submissions: Remove submissions (useful for maintaining database cleanliness or handling inappropriate content).
adminGuide.section_4_p7: Verdict Breakdown: Understand why submissions failed with colored status indicators.
adminGuide.section_4_p8: Pagination helps manage large submission lists efficiently.
adminGuide.section_4_p9: Export Data: Use the data to generate reports on user performance and problem difficulty.
adminGuide.section_5_p1: The Statistics page provides comprehensive insights into platform usage.
adminGuide.section_5_p2: User Statistics: Track total users, role distribution, and growth trends.
adminGuide.section_5_p3: Problem Statistics: See total problems, difficulty distribution, and solved rates.
adminGuide.section_5_p4: Submission Statistics: Monitor submissions by verdict, language, and time periods.
adminGuide.section_5_p5: Performance Metrics: Track system performance, resource usage, and response times.
adminGuide.section_5_p6: User Engagement: Identify active users, most popular problems, and trending challenges.
adminGuide.section_5_p7: Use this data to make informed decisions about content creation and platform improvements.
adminGuide.section_5_p8: Export reports for presentations, meetings, or official documentation.
adminGuide.section_5_p9: Identify bottlenecks: Problems with very low acceptance rates might need clarification.

teacherGuide.section_1_desc: Setting up your teacher account and understanding your role
teacherGuide.section_1_p1: Your TEACHER role gives you special privileges to create and manage coding problems.
teacherGuide.section_1_p2: Unlike regular users, you can design custom problems for your students or the community.
teacherGuide.section_1_p3: Access the Teacher Dashboard from the main navigation menu.
teacherGuide.section_1_p4: Your dashboard shows all problems you've created and their performance metrics.
teacherGuide.section_1_p5: You can see which students have attempted your problems and their success rates.
teacherGuide.section_1_p6: Use this insight to refine problem statements and adjust difficulty levels.
teacherGuide.section_2_desc: How to design effective coding problems
teacherGuide.section_2_p1: Start with a Clear Problem Statement: Write a clear, concise description of what students need to solve.
teacherGuide.section_2_p2: Specify Input/Output Format: Be very explicit about input format, output format, and constraints.
teacherGuide.section_2_p3: Set Appropriate Limits: Choose realistic time and memory limits based on expected solution complexity.
teacherGuide.section_2_p4: Create Representative Test Cases: Include both simple and complex test cases to thoroughly validate solutions.
teacherGuide.section_2_p5: Sample Test Cases: Provide 1-2 visible sample test cases to help students understand the problem.
teacherGuide.section_2_p6: Hidden Test Cases: Create additional hidden test cases to prevent hard-coded solutions.
teacherGuide.section_2_p7: Difficulty Level: Honestly assess the problem difficulty (EASY, MEDIUM, HARD).
teacherGuide.section_2_p8: Problem Tags: Add tags to help students find related problems and build skills progressively.
teacherGuide.section_2_p9: Review and Test: Before publishing, solve the problem yourself to ensure the solution is correct.
teacherGuide.section_3_desc: Understanding student performance and identifying learning needs
teacherGuide.section_3_p1: View All Submissions: See every student attempt on your problems.
teacherGuide.section_3_p2: Success Rate: Track what percentage of attempts result in accepted solutions.
teacherGuide.section_3_p3: Common Mistakes: Identify patterns in student errors - they might indicate unclear problem statements.
teacherGuide.section_3_p4: Verdict Distribution: Understand why students are failing (wrong answer, timeout, compilation error, etc.).
teacherGuide.section_3_p5: Languages Used: Track which programming languages students prefer.
teacherGuide.section_3_p6: Performance Data: See execution time and memory usage - identify if your limits are appropriate.
teacherGuide.section_3_p7: Struggling Students: Identify students who are having difficulty and may need additional support.
teacherGuide.section_3_p8: Fast Solvers: Recognize students who solve problems quickly and efficiently.
teacherGuide.section_3_p9: Use this data to refine your problem statements and adjust difficulty as needed.
teacherGuide.section_4_title: 4. Using CodeFix AI in Your Classroom
teacherGuide.section_4_desc: Integrating the platform into your teaching
teacherGuide.section_4_p1: Problem Sets: Create curated problem sets for each lesson or topic.
teacherGuide.section_4_p2: Progressive Difficulty: Order problems to gradually increase challenge as students improve.
teacherGuide.section_4_p3: Homework Assignments: Assign specific problems and use submission data to track completion.
teacherGuide.section_4_p4: Peer Learning: Encourage students to explain their solutions to classmates.
teacherGuide.section_4_p5: Debugging Practice: Use failed submissions as teaching moments - analyze why solutions failed.

guide.adminGuideDesc: Learn how to manage the CodeFix AI platform and administer all system resources
guide.teacherGuideDesc: Learn how to effectively create problems and manage your students' learning
guide.helpDescription: Check out the main instructions guide or contact support for technical assistance.
guide.title: How to Use CodeFix AI
guide.subtitle: A comprehensive guide to getting started and mastering the platform
guide.section_1_desc: Your first steps on the CodeFix AI platform
guide.section_1_p1: Welcome to CodeFix AI! This guide will help you navigate the platform and solve coding problems effectively.
guide.section_1_p2: CodeFix AI is an online judge platform that helps you practice programming through curated coding challenges.
guide.section_1_p3: Each problem includes a detailed description, sample test cases, and automatic evaluation of your submissions.
guide.section_1_p4: You can submit solutions in multiple programming languages: Python, C++, and JavaScript.
guide.section_1_p5: The platform provides instant feedback on your submissions with detailed error messages.
guide.section_2_desc: Learn how to read and understand problem statements
guide.section_2_p1: Each problem has a clear statement describing what you need to accomplish.
guide.section_2_p2: Pay attention to the Input/Output format section - this is crucial for correct solutions.
guide.section_2_p3: Read the constraints carefully: they tell you the valid ranges for inputs and expected solution efficiency.
guide.section_2_p4: Sample test cases show examples of input and expected output for the problem.
guide.section_2_p5: Hidden test cases will be used to evaluate your solution after submission.
guide.section_2_p6: The difficulty level (Easy/Medium/Hard) helps you choose problems appropriate for your skill level.
guide.section_3_desc: Best practices for writing correct and efficient code
guide.section_3_p1: Start by understanding the problem completely before writing code.
guide.section_3_p2: Test your solution with the provided sample cases first.
guide.section_3_p3: Think about edge cases: empty inputs, very large numbers, special characters, etc.
guide.section_3_p4: Write clean, readable code with meaningful variable names.
guide.section_3_p5: Comment your logic, especially for complex algorithms.
guide.section_3_p6: Optimize for both correctness and efficiency within the time and memory limits.
guide.section_4_desc: How to submit and track your submissions
guide.section_4_p1: Select your programming language from the dropdown menu.
guide.section_4_p2: Paste or load your code into the editor.
guide.section_4_p3: Click the Submit button to test your solution against all test cases.
guide.section_4_p4: You can make multiple submissions - there's no penalty for trying.
guide.section_4_p5: Each submission is timestamped and stored in your submission history.
guide.section_4_p6: The verdict shows whether your solution passed all test cases or where it failed.
guide.section_5_desc: How to interpret the results and feedback from CodeFix AI
guide.section_5_p1: ACCEPTED: Your solution passed all test cases! Congratulations!
guide.section_5_p2: WRONG_ANSWER: Your output doesn't match the expected result for some test case.
guide.section_5_p3: TIME_LIMIT_EXCEEDED: Your solution took too long to run - optimize your algorithm.
guide.section_5_p4: MEMORY_LIMIT_EXCEEDED: Your solution used too much memory - reduce data structures or optimize.
guide.section_5_p5: COMPILATION_ERROR: There's a syntax error in your code - check your language syntax.
guide.section_5_p6: RUNTIME_ERROR: Your program crashed - check for division by zero, array out of bounds, etc.
guide.section_5_p7: Use this feedback to improve your solution and try again.
guide.section_6_desc: Techniques to find and fix bugs in your code
guide.section_6_p1: Add print/console statements to track variable values during execution.
guide.section_6_p2: Test with the sample cases first - if those fail, your logic is definitely wrong.
guide.section_6_p3: Create your own test cases, especially edge cases like empty inputs or maximum constraints.
guide.section_6_p4: Trace through your code manually with a test case to see what it actually does.
guide.section_6_p5: Use a debugger if your IDE supports it - step through code line by line.
guide.section_6_p6: Review the problem statement again - you might have misunderstood a requirement.
guide.section_6_p7: Check for off-by-one errors, especially in loops and array indexing.
guide.section_7_desc: Write efficient solutions that run within time and memory limits
guide.section_7_p1: Choose appropriate data structures: use hash maps for O(1) lookups, not lists.
guide.section_7_p2: Understand Big O complexity: O(n¬≤) works for n‚â§1000, but O(n log n) is better for large n.
guide.section_7_p3: Avoid nested loops when possible - they multiply time complexity.
guide.section_7_p4: Use early termination: break out of loops when you find what you're looking for.
guide.section_7_p5: Profile your code: measure where time is actually spent before optimizing.
guide.section_7_p6: Read the constraints to understand what optimization level is needed.
guide.section_7_p7: Sometimes a simpler, clearer algorithm is fast enough - don't over-engineer.
guide.section_8_desc: Pitfalls to avoid when solving problems
guide.section_8_p1: Ignoring integer overflow: Large calculations might exceed data type limits.
guide.section_8_p2: Using 1-based vs 0-based indexing incorrectly - know which arrays start at 0.
guide.section_8_p3: Not handling negative numbers or zero as special cases.
guide.section_8_p4: Forgetting newlines in output or having extra spaces.
guide.section_8_p5: Assuming constraints are smaller than stated - always test with maximum values.
guide.section_8_p6: Logic errors like using AND when you mean OR, or vice versa.
guide.section_8_p7: Not considering floating point precision issues in mathematical problems.
guide.section_8_p8: Submitting without testing with sample cases first.
guide.section_9_desc: Professional coding habits that lead to success
guide.section_9_p1: Always start with a plan: pseudocode or algorithm before actual code.
guide.section_9_p2: Use version control: keep track of your solutions for future reference.
guide.section_9_p3: Comment your code: future you will thank present you.
guide.section_9_p4: Test thoroughly: sample cases, edge cases, and stress tests.
guide.section_9_p5: Refactor after solving: make your code cleaner and more efficient.
guide.section_9_p6: Learn from others: read accepted solutions to see different approaches.
guide.section_9_p7: Practice regularly: consistent practice improves problem-solving skills.
guide.section_9_p8: Don't just memorize solutions - understand the underlying concepts.
guide.section_10_desc: Important considerations for Python, C++, and JavaScript
guide.section_10_p1: Python: Use built-in functions and libraries (collections, itertools) for efficiency.
guide.section_10_p2: C++: Remember to include all necessary headers and watch for integer overflow.
guide.section_10_p3: JavaScript: Remember that numbers in JS can have precision issues - use BigInt for large integers.
guide.section_10_p4: All languages: Pay attention to how strings are handled and compared.
guide.section_10_p5: Know your language's standard library - don't reinvent the wheel.
guide.section_10_p6: Learn the typical template for competitive programming in your language.
guide.proTip_1: Always test with the sample cases first - if those fail, reread the problem statement.
guide.proTip_2: The constraints section tells you what optimization level is needed.
guide.proTip_3: Edge cases (empty, single element, maximum values) catch most bugs.
guide.proTip_4: When stuck, take a break and come back with fresh eyes.
guide.proTip_5: Read accepted solutions to learn new techniques and approaches.
guide.faq_1_question: Can I use external libraries or frameworks?
guide.faq_1_answer: Only standard libraries are available. You can use built-in functions and standard library imports for your language.
guide.faq_2_question: Why did my solution get Wrong Answer on a hidden test case?
guide.faq_2_answer: Your solution works for the sample cases but fails on other test cases. Check for edge cases, integer overflow, or logical errors.
guide.faq_3_question: How can I make my solution faster?
guide.faq_3_answer: Use more efficient algorithms and data structures. Avoid nested loops, use hash maps for lookups, and think about Big O complexity.
guide.faq_4_answer: Currently, CodeFix AI supports Python, C++, and JavaScript. More languages may be added in the future.
guide.faq_5_question: Can I see other users' solutions?
guide.faq_5_answer: Not yet. Our focus is on learning through your own problem-solving. In the future, we may add solution sharing features.
guide.faq_6_question: How can I improve my problem-solving skills?
guide.faq_6_answer: Practice consistently, start with easy problems, understand the concepts, read other approaches, and solve problems in different categories.

about.title: About CodeFix AI
about.tagline: Learn to code through competitive problem solving
about.section1Content: CodeFix AI is an online judge platform where you can practice coding problems, submit solutions, and get instant feedback. Whether you're a beginner learning the basics or an experienced programmer honing your skills, CodeFix AI provides problems of varying difficulty levels.
about.feature1: Hundreds of coding problems in multiple categories
about.step1: Create an account to track your progress
about.step2: Browse problems by difficulty and category
about.step3: Submit your solutions in your preferred language
about.step4: Get instant feedback and improve your code
about.teacherContent: CodeFix AI provides a comprehensive platform for educators to create problems, manage student submissions, and track learning progress with detailed analytics.
about.contactContent: For questions or feedback, please reach out to our community or check the documentation.

status.title: System Status
status.subtitle: Monitor the health of backend services
status.backendsOffline: If the Backend Server is offline:
status.backendOfflineStep1: Check if the backend server is running on your machine
status.backendOfflineStep2: Verify the NEXT_PUBLIC_BACKEND_URL environment variable is set correctly
status.backendOfflineStep3: Ensure backend is accessible at the configured URL
status.ollamaOffline: If the Ollama AI Server is offline:
status.ollamaOfflineStep1: Ensure Ollama is installed on your system
status.ollamaOfflineStep3: Verify OLLAMA_URL is set correctly in backend .env (default: http://localhost:11434)
status.ollamaOfflineStep4: Ensure a model is downloaded: ollama pull qwen2.5-coder:3b
status.generalTroubleshootingStep1: Try refreshing the page to re-check service status
status.generalTroubleshootingStep2: Clear your browser cache and cookies
status.generalTroubleshootingStep4: Review the backend and Ollama logs for detailed error messages

backendWarning.title: BACKEND SERVER UNAVAILABLE
